text: Cats can be allergic to humans - feline asthma, which affects 1 in 200 cats, can be triggered by human dandruff, cigarette smoke, and dusty houses.
Bloodcurdling is more than an expression - research shows watching horror movies can increase certain clotting proteins in our bloodstreams.
There is a medical term for ice cream headaches - sphenopalatine ganglioneuralgia, caused by rapid cooling of the capillaries in the sinuses.
Blood donors in Sweden receive a thank-you text message when their blood is actually used to help a patient.

Cats are susceptible to more than 250 hereditary disorders similar to human diseases, including retinitis pigmentosa, Feline Immunodeficiency Virus (related to HIV), and their own form of Alzheimer's Disease.
PFAS 'forever chemicals' have been linked to multiple sclerosis in a concerning new study published in 2026.
Cancer may emit protective signals that guard the brain against Alzheimer's disease - explaining a puzzling inverse relationship between the conditions.
U.S. life expectancy hit a record high in 2024 and could still be climbing.
A cheap daily vitamin D supplement may have surprising health benefits specifically for women.
Fact about lupus-like syndrome induced by Campylobacter jejuni CJ-S131: diseases causes.
Fact about motor developmental delay due to 14q32.2 paternally expressed gene defect: diseases causes.
Vitamin E was named 'tocopherol' as it was identified as essential for live births in rats.
Sammy Basso was the oldest known person with progeria.
Neurocysticercosis has been referred to as 'the great imitator' because it can mimic many other neurological disorders.
Many people who recover from tuberculosis lose more than half of their lung capacity.
Chronic pain syndromes affect approximately 20 percent of people and account for 15 to 20 percent of doctor visits.
Public health measures and advances in medical science in modern human history helped raise global life expectancy from about 31 years in 1900 to over 66 years in 2000.
The death rate from adrenal crises can reach as high as 6 percent.
Tudor Arghezi, 'perhaps the strongest personality in all of 20th-century Romanian literature', claimed that he could identify people with cancer by their smell.
Many women with polycystic ovary syndrome grow hair in a 'male' pattern, including facial hair.
Johann Joseph Dömling suggested in 1803 that venous blood contained carbon monoxide.
Alexander Langmuir created the Epidemic Intelligence Service to send epidemiologists across the world.
British physician John H. Bryant gave the first description of a blue scrotum caused by a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.
Niall Ó Glacáin, an Irish physician, worked as a travelling plague doctor in southern France in the 1620s.
The National Hospital Service Reserve trained volunteers to carry out first aid in the aftermath of a nuclear or chemical attack.
According to tradition, Saint Ludger healed the Frisian bard Bernlef of his blindness and taught him to play psalms on his harp.
The legalization of abortion in Benin was supported by two members of the cabinet who had both worked as gynecologists.

The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine (Swedish: Nobelpriset i fysiologi eller medicin) is awarded annually by the Swedish Karolinska Institute to scientists in the various fields of physiology or medicine.
While commonly referred to as the Nobel Prize in Medicine, Nobel specifically stated that the prize be awarded for "physiology or medicine" in his will.
The first Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine was awarded in 1901 to Emil Adolf von Behring, of Germany.
In 1939 Gerhard Domagk, a German, was not allowed by his government to accept the prize.
As of 2024, the prize has been awarded to 229 individuals, thirteen of them were women (Gerty Cori being the first to be awarded in 1947).
The longest time between twins being born is 87 days.
Fecal transplants can cure severe gut infections by introducing healthy bacteria from a donor.
Laughter actually is good medicine — it reduces stress hormones and boosts immune function.
Fever is actually your body fighting infection — the elevated temperature helps kill pathogens.
Bone marrow transplants can change a person's blood type permanently.
Maggot therapy is still used in modern medicine to clean wounds by eating dead tissue.
The placebo effect works even when patients know they're taking a placebo.
Doctors used to taste urine to diagnose diabetes — sweet urine indicated the disease.
Maggot therapy is FDA-approved and used to clean wounds.
Leech therapy is still used in modern medicine after reattachment surgeries.
Bee venom is being researched as a treatment for HIV.
Hookworm therapy is used to treat autoimmune diseases.
Fecal transplants can cure C. difficile infections with a 90% success rate.
The placebo effect works on animals and even operates on organs.
Blue dye from M&Ms may help spinal cord injuries.
A woman had a tumor that grew teeth and hair — a teratoma.
The longest time between twin births is 87 days.
Epigenetic therapy is used for some cancers.
5-azacytidine is an epigenetic drug.
HDAC inhibitors are epigenetic cancer treatments.
The inventor of the lobotomy won a Nobel Prize.
The longest hiccuping spree lasted 68 years - Charles Osborne hiccuped from 1922 to 1990.
The longest time between two twins being born is 87 days.
The longest time between two twins being born is 87 days apart.
The longest hiccup attack lasted 68 years, experienced by Charles Osborne.
The first 3D printed organ was a bladder, created in 1999.
A fetus can recognize its mother's voice in the womb starting around 24 weeks.
The first successful human heart transplant was performed by Dr. Christiaan Barnard in 1967.
The first successful vaccine was developed by Edward Jenner for smallpox in 1796.
The first antibiotic, penicillin, was discovered by Alexander Fleming in 1928.
The longest known lifespan of a human is 122 years, achieved by Jeanne Calment.
The first successful blood transfusion was performed in 1665 by Richard Lower.
The first successful kidney transplant was performed in 1954 by Dr. Joseph Murray.
The first artificial heart was implanted in 1982 into Barney Clark.
The first contact lens was made of glass and invented in 1888.
The first successful liver transplant was performed in 1967 by Dr. Thomas Starzl.
The first artificial pacemaker was implanted in 1958 by Dr. Ake Senning.
The first recorded use of anesthesia in surgery was in 1842 by Dr. Crawford Long.
The first successful cornea transplant was performed in 1905 by Eduard Zirm.
The first X-ray was taken in 1895 by Wilhelm Röntgen of his wife's hand.
The first successful hip replacement surgery was performed in 1960.
The first MRI scan was performed in 1977.
The first kidney dialysis was performed in 1943 by Willem Kolff.
The first successful polio vaccine was developed by Jonas Salk in 1955.
The first cardiac catheterization was performed in 1929 by Werner Forssmann on himself.
The first successful cesarean section where both mother and child survived was in 1500.
The first organ transplant from a genetically modified pig to a human was in 2022.
The first insulin injection for diabetes was given in 1922.
The first successful bone marrow transplant was performed in 1968.
The first successful lung transplant was performed in 1963.
The first successful face transplant was performed in 2005 in France.
The first successful hand transplant was performed in 1998.
The first pacemaker was implanted in 1958 and the patient outlived the surgeon.
The first test-tube baby was born in 1978.
The first successful gene therapy treatment was approved in 2017.
The first CRISPR gene editing in humans was performed in 2016.
The first robot-assisted surgery was performed in 1985.
The first 3D-printed medicine was approved by the FDA in 2015.
